reviewText: After first watching the 2011 "Time Machine" DVD where I thought Geddy's voice was just Horrible and shot, although the Band was fantastic! So I then decided to give this a watch. Geddy's vocals on this DVD are in perfect form! Now the Atlanta dicc though (disc 3) Geddy's voice is once again SHOT! So I guess with age, he had good night and bad nights. The main DVD's (1&2) is the Holland concert and it is incredible! It is a very long show, broken into 2 DVD's. Much of Snales and Arrows is played, along with great cuts from the past...Subdivisions, Witch Hunt, Limelight, ect. I found the picture quality to be excellent! Great job filming the show, editing wasn't too bad, the 5.1 mix though coulda been better, not much use of the back speakers I noticed, bit not bad over all. This is a MUST OWN DVD for any Rush fan! Geddy's voice as I said was just FLAWLESS and in top form! The Band was great as usual! This DVD is a great document of their 2008 tour and a great testiment that old men can still rock out!
summary: Geddy's Vocals are strong, Band was Superb!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Filmed with 21 high definition cameras in 16x9 widescreen format in October 2007 in Rotterdam, Holland, Snakes & Arrows Live is without a doubt, one of the best ever live concert DVDs. With a total running time of three hours and forty minutes, this three-disc set is a dream come true for any Rush fan. Discs one and two feature the 27-song concert from the Netherlands. This mammoth set list features nine songs from the Snakes & Arrows album alongside classics such as `Subdivisions' and `Tom Sawyer'. From the opening notes of `Limelight' to the final moments of `YYZ', vocalist/bassist Geddy Lee, guitarist Alex Lifeson and drummer Neil Peart are in fine form. Consummate professionals, they make the most intricate passages look effortless. The stage is set with Geddy's Henhouse rotisserie chicken ovens as well as Alex's toy dinosaurs and Barbie dolls. What sets Snakes & Arrows Live apart from previous Rush DVDs: R30 (2005) and Rush In Rio (2003) is the myriad number of up close and personal camera angles, highlighting the prodigious musicianship and on stage interaction. In fact, watching this DVD is almost better than actually being at the show. The bonus features include the absolutely hilarious skit, What's That Smell, which was used to introduce the second set. Who knew Alex and Geddy were such comedians? Disc three - Oh, Atlanta! The Authorized Bootlegs contains four songs added for the 2008 American tour. And the term bootleg is highly misleading. A fan in the rafters didn't capture these; they're entirely pro-shot. Completing the package is a 12-page booklet. The only thing missing is interviews with the band.
summary: RUSH - Snakes & Arrows Live

reviewText: If you are a long time Rush fan, or just getting to know the band right now, and you can afford only one concert DVD, this is the one I would recomend. This is by far the best sound and image quality in any Rush concert (and the other ones are not really too bad).The song set list is really interesting, including a good portion of new songs from their latest studio album, Snakes and Arrows, the classic hits like Tom Sawyer, The Spirit of Radio, 2112 and Limelight, and the long lost gems like Circumstances, A Passage to Bangkok, and Ghost of a Chance. The performance is unbelieveably solid, and it's full of the well-known Rush humor. Do not miss this one.
summary: Rush at it's best

reviewText: Rush is one of the greatest rock bands ever (hello Hall of Fame! Rush should be in the Hall of Fame by now) and I can't wait to pop these discs into my DVD player, IF I don't scratch the discs' surfaces. This has the same horrible packaging as Cheap Tricks' new "Budokan!" box. The CDs are incredibly snug in cardboard slits, all in a flimsy package. No clam shell case or even slimline jewel cases here. Just a flimsy cardboard package with no trays whatsoever, so every time you do get the discs out, they will scratch, no matter how careful you are. It's frustrating that labels keep having ANTI-JEWEL CASE FEVER and keep issuing things that will scratch after just a few days. Bring back the jewel cases, please. Which is worse for the environment, stacks and stacks of these flimsy cardboard/slit packages and the CDs/DVDs they scratch piled high in landfills, or jewel cases in our homes?Again, I am a massive Rush fan. I just hate the storage presentation in this case.  :(
summary: Love Rush like there's no tomorrow, but this has terrible packaging

reviewText: As a few others have mentioned, there's a split second timing difference between the video and the audio.  This is particularly noticeable when watching Neil hit the snare drum.  When the audio and video are out of sync, it completely ruins the viewing experience for me.  I own about 20 concert Blu Ray discs, and haven't noticed this problem with the other concerts, so it appears to be just poor editing on the part of the folks who edited this particular show.  Inexcusable.

reviewText: I'm so glad that I got to attend a couple of the shows from this tour, and this DVD is a gorgeous reminder of how good the shows were and how fantastic this band STILL is.I was very pleased with how well it is filmed, it looks stunning. And the 5.1 audio is spectacular! The guys are having a great time, you can see the joy. I couldn't help but smile. The set list is phenomenal, the musicianship, stellar. I cannot recommend this more highly.A SOLID FIVE STARS! What a great keepsake of a brilliant tour.I do have a couple of things that I need to mention. As well as this show was filmed, it almost suffers from today's INSATIABLE desire to shoot and edit in the "no attention span" mode. This show is nowhere edited as bad as Rush In Rio, but it still does not focus on the group or individual as long as it should, sustaining shots on solos, singing and such. You know what I mean. It's better than most, but could be better, still. Take a look at Neil Young's, Heart Of Gold. It is amazing.Second issue is the pathetic piece of paper packaging. I totally understand going "green", but I got this DVD for Xmas and the inside is torn up and folded. Plus the DVD's must be slid in and out, hence scratching the DVD surfaces. This is an issue that they need to improve on. I am considering contacting Amazon to see if I can get a replacement because of the torn, junk packaging. NO STARS for the packaging.
summary: This Was A Great Tour!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've been a Rush fan since 1912... kidding, since 1976.  The 'fossil' that I am, i've probably seen them at least 40 times live beginning with the 'Farewell To Kings' tour way back when.  I have all their CD's and DVD's.  I have played their LP's (vinyl records) on an old 'Fisher' tube stereo receiver with 'Realistic' (Radio Shack) speakers, and 8-track tapes back in the day (70's).  As an older '40-something' audiophile now thankfully making more than a high school kid did back then, I can now listen to them via high-end McIntosh equipment and Magneplanar hi-res speakers.  Rush never sounded better!  That said, and with my high expectations, this 'Snakes & Arrows' live DVD is INCREDIBLE, visually and sonic-wise!  THIS IS HOW A LIVE CONCERT DVD SHOULD BE DONE!  The camera work is stellar, with a good mix of closeups, medium range, and whole stage shots.  Audio is excellent, both in stereo and in 5.1.  And best of all, Rush is in absolute top form, moving, playing, and singing as if they were 25 again!  This is a MUST OWN concert for Rush and/or prog rock fans!
summary: STUNNING performance and DVD quality/sound!!!  A 'must own'!

reviewText: This is one of the best concert dvd's I've seen, and certainly the best of Rush's releases. It's about Rush and their performance. It is not about how 'creative' some idiot producer thinks he is when he cuts from one camera to another every second as some I've seen. It shows you camera angles from all over, upclose, and one on the Atlanta disk I 'm watching now that seems to be from the back row of the amphitheatre. If you want to know what it's like to see Rush, buy a ticket next time. For a most reasonable facsimile thereof, buy this DVD. If you're like me and you just love these guys and can't wait till next time, BUY THIS DVD.THANK YOU ALEX NEIL AND GEDDY.

reviewText: Although 'Snakes and Arrows' wasn't my favorite Rush tour/set, this is their best Live product they've put out. R30 and "Rio" were very good. This is even better. The HD looks terrific. The sound is great. The camera work is great. Even after 30+ years, Rush still knows how to put on an unbelievable show. Every live release should look and sound like this. Rush could have easily "overpackaged" this and sold it for twice as much, but they didn't. They put over 3 hours worth of great music together, and released it to their fans on Blu-ray for $20. Thanks Neil, Geddy, and Alex.

reviewText: This is an excellent DVD. I have a hard time giving anything Rush does since 1990 5 stars so this earns 4. It is the long sought after answer to what should be in the middle of their Grace Under Pressure DVD and Exit Stage Left..., the only reason is because of the inclusion of songs such as Circumstances, Digital Man, Entre Nous, Between The Wheels, Witch Hunt, Passage to Bangkok, Mission and some stunning camera and video quality here. RIO owns the rights probably forever for the concert that makes you wish you were really there. I mean that show is the standard for how all Rush crowds should act.Holland like Frankfurt on R30 and the UK for A Show of Hands suffers from sleepy crowd syndrome. This feels more like Rush playing to canned applause which takes the excitement away from it at times. Overall though one can't complain all that much. When they can make One Little Victory worth watching and Malignant Narcissism sound exactly like the record...they score big.Why they chose to pan so far away during Neil's solo however only leads me to believe it was a combo of both nights on audio and had to do so for the sake to sync with video.This is a must own for any Rush fan whether you like Snakes and Arrows or not. To me personally they played 4 songs too many from the record and could have swapped those out with Jacobs Ladder, Time Stand Still, Show Don't Tell, and Test For Echo by giving us some classics from the band that we do not have on dvd yet live by the band.
summary: The Answer To Exit and Grace

reviewText: I really didn't think they could produce a DVD that topped Rush in Rio.  That has been my Gold Standard of concert DVDs since I purchased it.  But Snakes and Arrows Live actually topped it. I won't bother to review the actual set-list, because song choice is a matter of personal taste.  What makes this DVD so good is the picture and sound quality. Most notably, the camera angles on the individual players were terrific.  They lingered just long enough for you to get a good look at their hands and see how they were playing.  But the shots weren't so tightly focused in on fingers as to be an instructional video. The wider shots incorporated just enough background to give you the feel of really being at a concert.  Of course the picture is crystal clear.  Finally, the sound quality is superb.  I was able to crank up my system to floor rumbling levels without any distortion at all. And you could hear the subtle differences of each of Neil's drum tones.If I was going to attempt to convert one of my non-Rush-loving friends, this is the DVD I'd use to do it.
summary: Much better than expected

reviewText: The GoodGrowing up I never professed to being the biggest Rush fan. In fact, I hated them. I've never owned a Rush album or enjoyed a song. I usually mock Geddy Lee's voice when one of their songs come in the radio. Once I was sent a copy of the Rush R:30 DVD in 2005, all that changed. I still don't care much for their music, but I respect it. The technical aspects, the live ambience, and the musicianship cannot be denied. So I was more than anxious to see if Snakes and Arrows Live lived up to the powerhouse that was R:30.This DVD collection is broken into three disc. Disc 1 features the first set of the main concert. "Limelight" kicks things off on this eleven song set, and Rush never look back. They make their intricate sounds look and sound so easy. The crowd is certainly into it and the sound quality is superb. Also on the first disc are the bonus features. The features included are promotional clips and videos for the Snakes and Arrows release, as well as alternate camera angles for the main concert. You even get a live performance left off the R:30 DVD. Be sure to check out the hilarious outtakes included on the disc.Disc 2 contains the second set of the concert (and most of the songs I recognize), as well as the encore set. The second DVD is just as superb as the first. There are no bonus features on this disc, but the third DVD could certainly fill that void. Disc three is titled Oh, Atlanta, The Authorized Bootlegs. This disc features five liver performances that didn't appear on the main DVDs.The BadNothingThe VerdictYou don't have to be a fan to enjoy a Rush concert. Snakes and Arrows Live features another fantastic performance by the Canadian prog-rockers. A must have for fans, and a must have for music lovers in general. Now if someone can explain the significance of the rotisserie on stage.
summary: You don't have to be a fan to enjoy a Rush concert

reviewText: Standing alone, this DVD is excellent. My own personal opinion is that I enjoyed previous releases better for the extra contents. I prefer "making of" shorts and documentaries in place of skits, sketches, and SNL performances. I'm sure they are more fun to create though. On a positive note, we know much more about them as individuals in the last 10 years because the performances are less canned. The concert footage has come a long way from the Rio performance that was thrown together after a rain storm. Still, I'm not sure I'd continue in the direction of comedy. The 20 years of serious music covered up a spontaneous sense of humor only sometimes seen live. Name a "video" on Chronicles that is not dated. In retrospect, I'll bet half of the RUSH videos (especially the obscure ones NOT on Chronicles) weren't lucrative financially for the trio. An online extra from the Colbert Report showed them failing to successfully play Tom Sawyer on the Rockstar game. THAT was classically funny. Appearances from Jerry Stiller, South Park, Bob and Doug etc. make the band to appear to be more mainstream. Dedicated Rush fans want them to remain our little secret. We'd also like them to get their due too. Like from the RNR Hall of Fame... AHEM!
summary: Movin' Them Pictures

reviewText: The Blu-Ray is good and worth having but I expected the recording quality to be much better.  The bass is just too weak.  The bass drums have no boom and the drums don't have enough presence.  I compared the track Monkey Business from the Snakes and Arrows DVD MVI album and compared it to the blu-ray.  The bass drum sound on the MVI version blew away the blu-ray version by a wide margin. On the other hand I found the cymbals on the blu-ray sounded better than the MVI.  Another annoying thing is the cameras constantly switch angles every three seconds.  If it were up to me I would put the camera on Neil and leave it there.  Putting aside the sound...the performance was very good.
summary: I expected more from a blu-ray release

reviewText: In a word, the Blu-Ray release of Snakes and Arrows is: Amazing.  I will caveat this review with the fact that I am a Rush fan, and have been for twenty years.  That being said, this concert, this show(s), this chapter in their career is a benchmark for others to follow.  In an interview I read, Geddy Lee indicated that this release was done for the fans.  To the viewer and fan, it is immediately evident.  Shots are much longer and cut to catch a fill of Neil's, the fretwork of Alex, or the plucking of Geddy.  Gone is the jerky editing of Rio and to a lesser extent R30.  If you never had the chance to sit in the front row (like me!) of a Rush concert, while still taking in the atmosphere of the stage from high in the back (much more like me!), now is your chance.  The HD imagery shows off details either us as fans, or concert goers, have not seen before.  You can almost count all of the hairs underneath Geddy's lower lip and read the label on Alex's jeans (Not that I really was trying mind you).  The image is simply impeccable and the view it gives you of their musicianship is phenomenal.  The DTS-HS audio puts you front and center.  Geddy's base is firmly to the right, Alex is on the left and Neil is all over the place.  The mix provides just the right amount of atmosphere from the crowd too.  During the Main Monkey Business, check out the crowd clapping along.  It is subtle, but brilliantly done.For a Rush experience, I know this is a disc I will go back to again and again.  This is not Rush flogging another live disc out there for the money, this is Rush throwing one out there for the fans. As a fan, I am glad that they did.
summary: Snakes & Arrows: Rush gets it right

reviewText: I'm pretty new to the Rush game, having been a fan for only about 6 or 7 years, but I quickly became inundated with most of their studio output & not long after that discovered what a powerhouse they were (and still are) as a live band.This may be my favorite Rush concert yet, the setlist is tremendous, combining the then new material from the excellent album "Snakes and Arrows" and blending in their more familiar staples such as "Tom Sawyer", "Freewill", "Distant Early Warning", "The Spirit of Radio" and pulling out an old, but very good and underplayed song such as "Between the Wheels."I liked "Time Machine Tour", loved the "Grace Under Pressure" concert & "Rush in Rio", but "Snakes And Arrows" live tops them all. I can only hope the forthcoming "Clockwork Angels" tour can kick as much butt as this one.5 stars no doubt.
summary: Excellent Rush concert...

reviewText: Yes, this probably is one of those must-own concert videos. The detail is great and the camera work is even better. You get to see a lot of the functioning of a live band that many concert videos leave out.The performance is great, too. The late-middle section does get a little long, but overall it's really good. Few bands can perform as well live as they do on recording (after many multi-track takes being edited like mad), but Rush is one that can (another is Pink Floyd).The only nit-picking I have is the box. It's not the standard plastic container but a cardboard rendition. It may be more environmentally correct, but I don't like it. Small item that shouldn't discourage getting this movie.
summary: Great Detail

reviewText: I've been a fan of and going to Rush concerts since Hemispheres. Saw them 5 times on the S&A; tour alone. They are wonderful musicians and performers. The live concerts rock. And this DVD is a great show but....Why oh why can't musicians of this quality get their act together and produce / engineer a consistent quality sounding product. Rush just seems to have more audio engineering issues than they should, (either lame washed out and tinny with no low end or over amped and distorted to the max), and this DVD is no different. As others have mentioned it lacks low end. Big time. Geddy's bass seems to be almost non existent sometimes. Neil's low end toms and kick bass drums have no oomph or punch at all. R-30's sound quality is better than this....Rio worse.Too bad cause the show is great. Hopefully they do at least one more tour and live shot and produce it with a quality audio engineer.
summary: Good preformance but once again poor sound.
Title: N/A

reviewText: RUSH: Snakes and Arrows Live [Blu-ray]It's incredible to see the picture quality on this Blu-ray. You can see the sweating on the guys and their wrinkles. The unreal quality of the colors is so impressive that with your own eyes you'll never be able to see that. The camera work is perfect with any kind of angle but for the most part, it offer some stunning close shots. The light show is captured also with some distant shots of the stage.
summary: Amazing!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw this tour in the Quad cities ( i-wireless Center also known as The Mark.) in may 2008. This was totally different sounding than my home theater and dvd.  The concert was much louder and had overblown bass especially at the beginning of Subdivisions. God it went through my body and all.  The drum solo was also loud and seemed shorter than the concert dvd.  The cymbels and snare and all pads blended together and really sounded bad.  The Dvd concert drum solo was awsome.  It was much different than the previous concert dvds (Rush in Rio and R30).  What I enjoyed most about this concert tour is that they played Witch Hunt and YYZ and Red Barchetta from one of their most popular album.  Would have liked if they played Time Stand Still, But  perhaps another time.  The Sound of the concert Recording was excellent as was the picture.  I remember the green lasers at the live concert I attended and they were mesmerising.  No T.V. or Dvd can reproduce the real thing so I'll leave that at that.  I take my hat off to those reviewers who reviewed this dvd before its release and gave it 5 stars.  It is a 5 star dvd Blu-ray or regular ray.  I Feel the disc was well Mixed (soundwise)  Alex's Guitar was probably a little louder than the drums and Geddy's voice was about right.  They could have boosted the drums a little.  They seemed a little louder on Neil's solo.  The crowed noise was perfect for me.  Not covered up at all.  I know that some people thought the crowd noise was rediculously overbering in the Rio dvd.  In a live concert you do hear the crowdnoise.  Definitely worth buying.  P.S. I forgot to mention that Geddy did admit to the crowd after the first set that they had chicken and there was plenty of it cooking on stage.  But the guy who was messing with the rotisseree was a regular Joe at the concert I attended.  Also the guy sitting in front of me had a copy of the set list of the show and at  the bottom it say's Version 3.  I practically begged him if I could buy it off him and he gave it to me.  What a night it was.
summary: No Limbaugh here, Just one great show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Okay so here is what you will not get watching from the new Rush "Snakes & Arrows Live" blu ray:*You won't see a band dressed up in gaudy costumes and wearing really horrible make- up*You won't witness singer  Geddy Lee asking the crowd, "Is there anyone here who wants to rock tonight?" or " Left hand side scream as loud as you can.  Okay now right hand side.  You scream louder than that left hand side"*You won't get a power ballad while the camera shows various audience members holding up lighters (Or is it cell phones now?) and getting shots of different women  on the verge of a break down.*And thankfully, you won't get the show put on hold while a band member who thinks he is a political science major lectures the audience about which candidate they should vote for.Rush is better than all of that.  This first Rush blu ray (and I hope there are many more to come) is a fine example of what a live DVD should be for many reasons:I've seen Rush many times in concert over the last quarter century and for the first time in ages the band has really shaking up it's set list.  It's dropped many perennial songs in favor of such rarities such as "Digital Man", "Circumstances", "A Passage To Bangkok", "Mission", and "Entre Nous", the last having never been played live.  Like many Rush fans I was not really into a lot of their nineties material (didn't hate it, just didn't find it as good as their earlier catalogue) so all the songs from the era, save "Dreamline" are gone.  Now the band does something that is almost unheard of for a band as old as Rush and that is play nine songs from it's most recent release, "Snakes & Arrows".  I seriously doubt the Stones would do such a thing. But the songs from "Snakes & Arrows" are welcome here as that CD is the best recording they have done in years and the songs sound brilliant live.The camera work blows away that of the previous two Rush concert films.  I found "Rush in Rio" a victim of over editing and was annoyed by so many shots of the crowd.  "R30" was a vast improvement but a third of the show was missing!  Here we get the entire gig, including intro and outro videos.  The main focus this time is the band playing.  The cameras capture almost every angle of the stage including seeing set lists taped up on Geddy Lee's keyboard and Neil Peart's drum.  It also needs to be noted that the high definition quality is outstanding.  After watching this video it's hard to go back and watch the older films. Again, I hope they find their way to blu ray sooner than later.The extra material is okay.  Fans will get "Red Sector A" which was omitted from the previously mentioned "R30" DVD as well as both "Far Cry" and "The Way The Wind Blows" performances with the camera focused on the rear screened happenings which is a lot of fun.  The outtakes I could take or leave.  I wasn't impressed with "What's that Smell" video that opened the second half of the 2008  leg of the tour but I am not going to knock the DVD for that.  Overall Rush has provided their fans with a real treat. Peace, and enjoy.
summary: A Bench Mark As Far As Concert Videos Go
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just received my copy of this blu-ray disc. I was a little apprehensive buying this as there is no indication as to what audio format is used and that is VERY important to me as I do have a fairly nice theater setup. Unfortunately, little information is given neither here and on the blu-ray cover other than the cover showing the standard 5.1 surround icon and PCM stereo as well. Amazon has nothing and you guys (Amazon) should start trying to address this "problem" as some of us out here would like to know in advance what we should expect. I'm happy to report that this disc is supplied with the DTS HDMA lossless format and it sounds marvelous...... it looks great as well. For any of you who might have been holding off buying this blu-ray due to audio issues, hold off no longer. It sounds great and really exemplifies what "lossless" can do for your surround sound system.Someone in another review stated that the bass was weak. I found that not to be the case and would suggest to the reviewer that he (or she) look into the bass management adjustments on their surround system or blu-ray player if it has the capability. I'm currently using an OPPO 83SE player and am running 7.1 analog out to my preamp. The OPPO does all the speaker management and am happy with the results which includes bass management.
summary: Snakes and Arrows Blu-ray audio revealed

reviewText: After I purchased my first blu-ray player, I bought the blu-ray version of this and R30 at the same time. After the extremely disappointing Rush In Rio dvd, I was pleasantly suprised about the quality of Snakes And Arrows live.Audio: As far as audio quality is concerned, this is the best live Rush concert video they have ever released. When you play it loud, it sounds like you're actually there. The drums have sort of a raw feel to them. Everything is crystal clear and sounds perfect.Video: For the most part, the video editing is perfect. With the exception of 2 songs, the video editing is they way it should be: not fast-paced MTV-style whit the camera angle changing every 1/8th of a second. For some reason, the video editing IS that annoying fast-paced style during Far Cry and One Little Victory, but thankfully, it's only during those 2 songs.I would highly recommend this dvd to any Rush fan, or even anyone who considers themselves a "part-time" fan who only knows their hits. Get the R30 dvd, too.They filmed the Cleveland show of the Time Machine tour earlier this month, so hopefully you will have a 3rd awesome blu-ray show to enjoy.
summary: almost perfect!

reviewText: I thought every piece of this bluray was phenomenal, compared to EVERY concert dvd/BD I own or have ever seen. This one blows them away! The video was spectacular, audio was awesome and the bootlegs almost made me cry they were so good. Yes I'm a Rush fan but this thing blew my mind, best BD I own by far. If you're a Rush fan this is the holy grail, all other dvd's pale in comparison. This is the concert I've waited to own my whole life!!!

reviewText: I was just thinking about it and it occurred to me that this is a perfect product for me to review. Why? Rush has been my favorite band since 1978. Ok, Dream Theater has tied that mark since 1992, but I digress... I am a semi-professional photographer (i.e. picture quality) for 6 years (and a photographer for 35 years & have been a more than obsessive hobbyist, but the recording kind (6 CD's in the last 18 years), musician for 25 years, with Rush as one of my key influences. And of course, I've seen them on every tour since 1980 and I saw them 5 times on the tour from which this was culled. So, OK, it's not from a neutral perspective. But it is from a very knowledgeable perspective. This review is from one Rush fan to another...With that said, having seen the show twice on leg 1 and 3 times on leg 2, I can say the contents of this DVD compared to my memory of the five shows I saw ranks equal to the second best of those two and thus slightly less than the best show out of all five.The first leg shows were unique in that not 1, but 3 songs that either had not been played live at all (Entre Nous) or not in roughly 24 years or more (Digital Man, Circumstances) were included in the setlist. Only Digital Man remained from those 3 in the second leg. However, Ghost of a Chance, a gem of a song from Roll the Bones, which had been sadly ignored since that tour, was added in place of Entre Nous on the second leg and a few more classic standards were played as well. This tour included the most material from a new album by Rush (Snakes & Arrows) since the late 80's, and the quality of the newest album warranted this.Rush is the type of band that likes to settle on a set list and continue perfecting the execution of it throughout the tour. From a very old interview, I recall them saying they wanted every fan to have the same experience. This would explain the similarity in the show throughout a tour. The nature of their perfectionism seems to allow them to do this and stay interested.Anyway, to specify the items which I believe are highlights, I would say that Digital Man is definite highlight. The arrangement is altered slightly to remove the middle iteration of the bridge and head straight into the solo section, and execute the bridge as only an outro with Geddy Lee jamming the bass out on it instead of being locked to a keyboard. That part always seemed awkward and what they did in terms of arrangement was precisely what I had hoped for. Oddly, though this is a highlight, I believe that Alex nailed the solo slightly better on several of the shows I saw, especially the one in Orlando, which is why I rate it higher. He still nails it here, just slightly sloppier on the fast lick. I'm nitpicking, but it's true.The next highlight is Freewill. Surprisingly, since I thought the Exit Stage Left version was so perfect. And while that's true, there are several reasons why this one stands close to that, or alongside it. First, the solo section is simply amazing. In particular, the camera work - which is stunning throughout this video - is absolutely amazing on this song's solo section. It has to be seen to be believed and the band just nailed it too. Perhaps the Exit Stage Left guitar shreds slightly hotter and Neil drums a little harder then, but there's a maturity in the execution here that compensates, and the intensity level is still so high, it shouldn't be plausible for men their age, LOL. Oh yea, and Geddy nails the high notes on the Bridge, just as he did in each of the shows I saw.There are many, many more highlights, and every song lives up to any other version you may have seen elsewhere, so I won't belabor each one in agonizing detail.I will move onto sound quality. This is the best sound quality of the three modern era videos/DVD's they've released, hands down. I have a DVD version as well that I play if I'm somewhere where Blu Ray isn't convenient. So I've played the audio through both my surround system in my house and through the system in my car's DVD/CD/NAV. In the car, when choosing the surround option, I have noticed that Geddy's bass sound stands out in a way where his tone is particularly distinguishable and it is positively perfect. It has the growl, the grind, of his Moving Pictures sound. The Fender Jazz is the reason and it is doing the job superbly. Every instrument is clear and powerful, both crisp and punchy at the same time, and they sound excellent in both the car and at home. A stellar job.Finally, I will get to the camera work. This is as much a highlight of this DVD as Rush is. The work is so good throughout it absolutely slays the rest of their videos. In Blu Ray it is possible to see the crispness of the work also. You realize how quickly and precisely these excellent professionals obtain and maintain subject focus. This has to be one of the best crews I've seen. I know it's at least partly automated because of the occassional view of the auto camera sliding across the front of the stage. And there are numerous angles, allowing a perfect mix of angles for the Rush fan to see. Every time you think they couldn't get tighter, the angle gets tighter. This is ultimately typified by the work on Freewill, as mentioned above.One thing I would elaborate on is to get into the Bonus material from Atlanta. I do not feel this crew did quite as good a job as the Rotterdam crew. It was good but not at that level. This is especially noticeable immediately. On the first song, Ghost of a Chance, there is a lot of Red in the lighting. As a photogrpher that attempted to photo this band in the early 80's (when they were still cool enough to let you bring in a 35mm SLR), I know Red is the biggest pain in the tush for getting sharp pictures. Nevertheless, these are pros getting paid big money, and the shots are clearly back focused and Geddy is softly focused. There are a few other instances in this 26 minutes of Bonus material where you see the slightly lesser quality of the work by the cameraman.Having said that, I would like to point out that I have also watched this on DVD on a standard resolution TV. And I would like to say that this Bonus material offers the perfect opportunity for anyone trying to convince their spouse or whomever that Blu Ray is significantly better, the reason why that is. The focus issue that was utterly obvious on Blu Ray is totally undiscernible on a standard resolution TV. It's already so much softer, it's evened out. It's a perfect tool to make that point completely clear.The setlist here has quite a few of the standards but contains so much material that is newly available, it is well worth it for that reason alone. However, this is a Top Quality performance among Top Quality Shows - clearly among the best. And this is the best camera work I've ever seen on a live DVD. The audio is at least nearly the best, if not the best, that I've heard as well. Pure quality on every front.
summary: Quite simply... Awesome!

reviewText: I managed to pick this up Saturday, Nov. 22, and watched it sat night. Great Work by the boys from up north. First the sound quality is really, really good, the setlist is great. (I saw them on each leg of Snakes And Arrows tour, and they played the best I have ever seen them play.) What makes this DVD Really special is the camera work, they focus on the boys playing and on stage interaction. All concert DVDS should be filmed this way...
summary: The way Concert DVDS should be filmed!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have everything Rush has ever sold. This is the finest concert recorded .......ever. The performance, lights , sound, ans song selection are the best they have ever done. I have seen them so many times that there are those great songs they never do......here they have performed many of their best that they never perform with many standards. Witch Hunt alone was worth the purchase. I am now buying the Blue Ray version since I got a player. Their other dvds are great but this is best recording of a music performance ever.....not just another compilation of what you have already seen. The filming is breathtaking and there are lots of humorous moments too. Neil Peart seems to be out of his funk he has seemed to be in for so long and that makes me very glad for him. He is one of my personal heroes and my favorite drummer of all time.
summary: Finest Rush product ever
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rush adds another great DVD to their catalog - this one is as good as R30.  Nice crisp picture, terrific sound (I watched in 5.1 with a 'rock concert' setting on my system and it rocked).  Very generous set list and even the so-called 'bootleg' songs are very good (not sure why they called them bootlegs as the quality is quite good).  Excellent camera work and great editing, plus the extras on disc one are nice additions.  Rush is a band made for the DVD medium.  The band shows off their sense of humor in some of the short clips and totally tears it up onstage.  Now that i think of it, having seen them many times, i don't think they ever give less than 100% onstage, and this DVD reflects it.  Excellent value for the money.  Here's hoping maybe they can bring out some vintage shows next......
summary: GREAT DVD - a must own for any Rush fan
